RAISING OF COMPULSORY RETIREMENT AGE

     1.  Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Manpower whether he will consider raising the compulsory retirement age and, if so, when will it be done.

    The Minister of State for Manpower (Mr Gan Kim Yong) (for the Minister for Manpower):  Mr Speaker, Sir, over the past two years, the employment rates of Singapore residents between the age groups of 55-59 and 60-64 have risen significantly.  For the 55 to 59 age group, it increased from 56% in 2004 to 61% in 2006.  For the 60 to 64 age group, it rose from 34% in 2004 to 42% in 2006.   The employment rates of older Singapore male residents in particular, at 78% for the 55 to 59 age group and 60% for the 60 to 64 age group in 2006, are higher than the OECD average and many developed countries, although we still trail Japan and Sweden.  This improvement has been mainly due to the good economic growth leading to expanded employment opportunities.  The efforts by the tripartite partners have also facilitated this improvement through various schemes and initiatives.

 

     We will continue to take this approach of growing the economy and working in conjunction with our tripartite partners to seek effective ways to raise the effective retirement age for older workers. The Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers in its Interim Report last year recommended a more flexible model of legislation where employers are required to offer some form of re-employment to workers who reach the retirement age, although not necessarily the same job on the same terms.   Such a system was introduced in Japan in April 2006 and a tripartite study group visited Japan in October last year to study its experiences.  The Tripartite Committee is evaluating the results of their re-employment legislation system. This will help us determine if this form of legislation is suitable and effective for Singapore.

 

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): May I ask the Minister of State whether now is an opportune time to raise the retirement age due to the number of jobs created last year, and is it not time now to get more older workers to join the workforce or delay retirement to contribute to the workforce when the labour is tight?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:   Mr Speaker, as I explained in my speech just now, we are taking various measures to encourage older workers to continue to stay in the workforce.  We are also introducing a lot of initiatives to encourage employers to shift their mindset and to accept older workers in their workforce. We are studying the Japan's system of encouraging older workers to work.  So I think, at the moment, our focus is on practical ways to encourage older workers to remain in the workforce, rather than to look at the retirement age.

     Mr Speaker:  One last supplementary question.

     Dr Lily Neo:  Thank you, Mr Speaker.  May I ask the Minister of State how does MOM prepare for this ageing population and ageing workforce?  Are there new avenues for upgrading and employment of older workers?  How do you encourage employers to accept older workers?  The last question is: how do you promote lifelong learning and nurture lifelong employability?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, through our various schemes, especially under the Advantage! Scheme which was announced some time last year, we have come out with a suite of measures to encourage older workers to continue to upgrade themselves. We are also working with NTUC to carry out job redesign so that certain jobs which were not suitable for older workers will be made suitable for them.  We are also working with the employers' representatives, SNEF as well as SBF, to work with employer groups to change the work practices in the work places to make them more suitable for older workers and to also help employers change their mindset to be more receptive to older workers. Through all these measures, we will continue to encourage our workers to work longer in preparation for an ageing population and an ageing workforce.

 

     With regard to her question on lifelong learning, we will continue to pursue lifelong learning both through the WDA as well as the training institutions.

Column No : 3045

PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP SCHEME AND BEST SOURCING

     2. Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) how will the Government rate its Public Private Partnership Scheme and outsourcing projects to date; (b) what are the measures being used to measure the success of these initiatives; (c) which projects have provided good returns and which have notably fallen short of expectations beyond reasonable limits; and (d) are there any new models being considered for the near future.

     The Minister of State for Finance (Mrs Lim Hwee Hua) (for the Prime Minister and Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Private Partnership (PPP) and Best Sourcing efforts in the Government are progressing well. 

 

     Best Sourcing is really about finding more cost-effective alternative service providers for non-strategic functions so that the public service resources can be directed at core functions. It is not about cost cutting or outsourcing or cheap sourcing. Since April 2004, the public sector has market-tested about 230 or 18% of its non-strategic functions.  70% of these functions were subsequently outsourced with an aggregate contract value of about $1.8 billion, yielding an annual operational cost savings of at least $34 million. The success of these initiatives can be measured by the extent of market-testing and cost savings, whilst maintaining service or performance standards. 

 

     Outsourcing of car park management by HDB and URA is a good example. Through the Best Sourcing exercise, HDB and URA expect annual savings of 20%, or $4 million per year.  Another recent example is the Ministry of Manpower’s award of a 3-year contract for the provision of integrated contact centre services (comprising a call centre, email handling and web services), which brought about significant improvements in the service levels.

 

     Best Sourcing is a complex exercise and agencies have to move at a pace which allows for changes without affecting the quality of service to the public, and without creating unnecessary anxiety and uncertainty for their staff.  Nonetheless, MOF will continue to encourage and help public agencies to undertake more Best Sourcing. 

 

     As for Public Private Partnership (PPP), we have only started them not too long ago.  So far, four PPP deals have been awarded - two by PUB for water treatment, one by NEA for incineration and another by Singapore Customs for TradeExchange.  The projects are not yet in full operation but we expect the benefits to be great as the PPP providers are able to optimise the whole lifecycle costing as it designs, builds, operates and maintains the facility.  The public sector will then buy services from the provider, instead of directly owning and operating these assets. 

 

     Sir, we are working on more PPP deals.  The Sports Hub by the Singapore Sports Council and the new ITE College West by ITE have just closed their tenders on 28th  February 2007.

 

     The public sector will consider the most appropriate method of procurement and will continue to explore new ways with the objective of always deriving the greatest value for money.  

 

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Mr Speaker, I would like to ask the Minister of State how does the Government ensure that the Best Sourcing does not become cheap sourcing.  Are the contracts awarded to the lowest tender or is it based on outcome?  For instance, is there any auditing for the Ministries to determine whether CPF is paid and labour laws are complied for workers so that it is not cheap sourcing?

     Mrs Lim Hwee Hua:  Sir, the Government would take all steps to ensure that in any Best Sourcing initiative, minimum standards will continue to apply, in terms of service delivery to the public, and that shall be the baseline.  Therefore, it will not always be the cheapest tender, but it will be the cheapest subject to minimum standard being complied with.  In some cases, the status quo is actually the Best Source, and it remains so.  As regards the suppliers who are ultimately awarded, it is actually a slightly different issue.  We would certainly expect the suppliers to comply with all the standard labour laws.  And certainly, if the Member is aware of anyone who is not complying with them, the Member is welcome to direct this to the attention of the Ministry.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):  What sort of changes in KPIs have the Government adopted or is considering adopting to take advantage of our Government sector flexibility and agility through these PPP's initiatives or even Best Sourcing initiatives?

     Mrs Lim Hwee Hua: Sir, currently, the KPIs evolve over time and the KPIs would, in most cases, be the minimum standard that Ministries would have to deliver.  Should the PPPs be successful, in terms of discovering greater technologies, then the KPIs would be amended accordingly.

     Head O - Ministry of Health (cont.)

 

     Resumption of Debate on Question [6th March, 2007],

 

     "That the total sum to be allocated for Head O of the Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mdm Halimah Yacob].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

 

     The Minister for Health (Mr Khaw Boon Wan): Mr Chairman, Sir, I will continue with my reply yesterday which was interrupted. 

 

     Mdm Halimah's queries are related to two important subjects, ie, how best to subsidise the needy, and how to ensure that care for the rich does not affect care for the poor.  We do not apply the subsidy formula mechanically, eg, every Class C bill, subsidise 80% or Class B2 bill subsidise 65%.  This is because there are many ways to treat the same illness.  For instance, we promote generic substitution, ie, the use of generic medicine which is cheaper but effective, instead of branded goods.  This way, we save on healthcare costs.  But sometimes, some subsidised patients insist on getting the more expensive branded medicine.  We oblige, but we get them to pay more for the non-standard drugs or implants.  Otherwise, the subvention budget would be depleted by such subsidised patients who obviously can afford better care and are demanding more.  This will disadvantage the truly needy who accept the basic but adequate care that we prescribe.  And there is an added reason.  For very expensive care, such as in the intensive units, we actually subsidise much more than the standard 65% or 80%.  The cost of running ICU is very, very high.  And if we were to simply apply the standard subsidy rate, many such patients would not be able to cope.  This is the reason why subsidy rates differ from nursing homes to expensive acute hospitals and why we apply a lower subsidy rate for outpatients than inpatients. 

 

     After all the mathematics are done, what patients are really most concerned about is the dollar quantum they have to pay and not so much how many percent of the bill that they are paying.  This way, we better ensure that the needy can afford their healthcare. 

 

     As for rich foreign patients crowding out the poor, I am very alive to this concern.  The solution is to ramp up supply of doctors, nurses and bed, and this is what we are doing, as I outlined yesterday.  The solution is not to say we do not treat rich or foreign patients in public hospitals.  Remember that doctors are mobile.  While they are mindful of their public duties, they also want to treat a range of patients, rich and poor.  If we unduly restrict their practice, some will simply pack up and go, and the poor will then be denied of their expertise.  But I agree fully with Mdm Halimah that our accounting should be clear and that we do not end up with subsidised patients subsidising the rich patients by unwittingly shouldering part of the cost of private care.

 

 

     Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng (Jalan Besar): Sir, I refer to the Minister's vision of one Electronic Medical Record (EMR) for one Singaporean, and also for both public and private sector medical practitioners to share the information when the database is up.  Can the Minister comment on:

 

     (1)  How Singaporeans' medical records can be kept confidential under such a system?

 

     (2)  Whether each citizen is empowered with the decision to share or not his personal medical records, because it can be quite intrusive and, in fact, dangerous for such personal medical records to be go around if it is not protected.

 

 

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Sir, this is indeed a very important subject, and that is part of the reason why "one Singaporean, one EMR" will take some time to implement.  Therefore, we will have to do it gingerly and carefully.  Otherwise, once information starts going around in the virtual world, it is very troublesome.  All countries are grappling with this problem.  My approach is to take it step-by-step.  That is why we focus on public hospitals first, because it is easier for us to manage our own doctors and nurses.  Once we are confident - and we are reasonably confident - my next step is going down to step-down care, eg, nursing homes, VWOs, etc.

 

     The key point is that we will have to decide what are the critical data.  Some data are so sensitive that they will never be shared.  So it does not mean that "one Singapore, one EMR" means all the gory details are out in outer space.  It cannot be.  We have to decide.  For example, issues like HIV and sexual diseases, these are data that we keep highly confidential.  In any case, do not get the wrong impression that electronic medical records will worsen this problem.  This problem exists even in paper form.  When we run hospitals, we know that with medical records on paper, any hospital staff with a badge, can walk into the records office, in the name of checking out the medical records of their patients.  You never know what happens in the office.  Whereas now, with electronic medical records, we can actually audit them.  So, let us say, we have a staff who, for various reasons, checks into the medical records of all kinds of patients who are not his patients, in the paper world, it is very hard to audit.  But in an online world, it is so easy.  There are softwares that can pick up very quickly; if you have a hundred patients, why are you accessing 1,000 patients' records?  There is no reason for you to do so.  Unfortunately, it does happen.  The system is able to pick it up.  I remember there was a case where we have to terminate the service of the staff.

 

 

     Dr Lily Neo: Mr Chairman, Sir, may I ask the Minister how does he maintain the high standard of our medical personnel?  In the past, doctors were sent overseas for training under the HMDP scheme.  Are there better avenues and more funding presently?  Does he have any plan to scale greater heights of medical expertise and medical excellence?  The Minister said yesterday that MOH is getting hundreds of foreign graduates to join our Ministry.  Could I urge him to be mindful of the quality of doctors and not just the quantity?

 

 

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan: On both points raised by Dr Neo, I totally subscribe to her views.  One is that we must continue to train, because medical science continues to evolve and we cannot stand still.  HMDP, which is a programme that we created many years ago to send doctors overseas and to attach them to some of the best centres of the world, continues to expand, and we are pumping in more money each year.  More importantly, in recent years, we have extended it beyond doctors, because the medical system comprises - no doubt, doctors form a big part - also nurses and allied health workers who are very important.  Each year, when I give away such scholarships to our staff, I am glad to see that besides a large number of doctors, also large numbers of pharmacists, radiographers, etc, and we should continue this way.

 

      The second point is about the quality of intake of foreign doctors.  Yes, that is why we study the medical degrees very carefully before we put them on the approved schedule.  I have progressively expanded it.  My operating principle is a simple one:  all the top medical schools of  major countries ought to be on our approved list.  There is no reason to exclude them.  But it does not mean that once a degree is recognised, you can just come in and set up shop, because, first, we only give a conditional registration.  So when you come in, you must have an employer and, practically all the time, it is the public hospitals.  My point to the CEOs is this:  yes, you can have a recognised degree, but you never know until the fellow appears and works for a few weeks or months.  Please watch over him very carefully in the first few months because, whether it is medical competence, or more importantly, it is his ethos and values, and those are very hard to check on paper.  If we are too strict in taking them in, then we are missing out on opportunities.  So I would rather be a little bit loose in taking in, but be very prompt, firm and decisive in throwing them out.  If you find that the fellow is just not up to our ethical standards and competence, we will be the first one to throw him out.  So, yes, it is not chasing numbers.  Numbers are important, but quality as well because, at the end of the day, it is the Singapore brand of medicine which is at stake here.

 

 

     Assoc. Prof. Kalyani K Mehta (Nominated Member): Mr Chairman, Sir, I have three points of clarification.  The first one is very straightforward.  In the step-down care system of health and social services, is the RAF form mentioned yesterday used across all the 20-odd services?  Is there any system of seeking feedback from all the different professionals, such as doctors, nurses, social workers, etc?  Is there any system of seeking feedback as to the adequacy of the form in order to improve it?  Lastly, for means testing of MOH and MCYS services in the step-down care sector, are there steps being taken to make the two consistent, because I believe there is a little bit of inconsistency there?   

 

 

     The Minister of State for Health (Mr Heng Chee How): Mr Chairman, Sir, my understanding is that the RAF form is used within the system.  The form was introduced to enable a simple way to assess those needs.  As I explained yesterday, the process of looking at the adequacy of the form is a continuous one, and we constantly look out for new methods, including the interRAI. 

 

     The question on whether stakeholders are consulted as to the adequacy of the form and what might be its shortcomings, this would also be an important part of the ongoing communications.  If there are inadequacies, then they can also be improved upon.

 

      Finally, on the possibly different criteria in means testing used in nursing homes versus the homes run by MCYS, I do not have the details with me here.  But I would certainly take the Member's feedback and we would make a check of it, and if there is a need to synchronise and harmonise them, we will do so.

 

 

     Mrs Josephine Teo (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Chairman, Sir, I would just like to thank the MOS for responding to my question on mental healthcare yesterday.  I was glad to note that mental healthcare patients are given proportionately more support through Medifund.  I would like to ask the question of whether the IMH has sufficient capacity to cater to demand because, from time to time, we hear of cases of mental healthcare patients who are discharged and have returned home where it would appear that they would be better off with longer term care at the IMH.

 

 

     Mr Heng Chee How: Mr Chairman, Sir, I thank the Member for her comment.  From the perspective of the Ministry, and certainly from IMH, supply adequacy will be a factor we will always bear in mind.  In other words, it is not a question of defining a certain supply and then, once you reach that, you push everybody out even though they may need inpatient care.  But neither do you want to then make every case an inpatient case unnecessarily, because the considerations must be the early re-integration of the person into wider society so that he or she might be able to function normally and live a full and fulfilling life.  So there is the medical aspect of this, ie, the assessment by the doctors as to what might be the right thing to do for an individual case, and this is also ongoing.  Certainly, as the population changes in profile, as it ages, and as more stress comes upon society, the demand patterns may shift and this is something that is also monitored by the Ministry as well as by IMH.

 

 

Suitable resources will be directed to the improvement of the supply, if need be.

 

12.30 pm

 

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Sir, just a couple of clarifications. Whilst I agree with the Minister that in those cases of subsidised patients where they request for more expensive medicine or implants, then that should not attract subsidies, but in the majority of cases, these patients are not in a position to request for more expensive implants or medicine.  In those cases where it is the doctor who prescribes that as part of the treatment procedure, would the Ministry then consider extending the same level of subsidy, rather than excluding them completely from the subsidy, because there are still some items which are completely excluded from subsidy and that is expensive and causes hardship?

 

    My second point is that the Minister said that what is important to the patient is, at the end of the day, the dollar quantum.  I would like to ask whether the Ministry tracks, in terms of dollar quantum, whether there has been an increase.  And if so, does the Ministry have a mechanism in place in the hospitals and other care providers to check why these increases are taking place? That leads me to the third question about wastage and duplication. I think there are two hospital clusters.  The concern continues that there are duplication and wastage. Are there any initiatives in the Ministry to track to ensure that cost does not increase because of wastages and duplication between the two clusters?

 

 

     Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Sir, I thank Mdm Halimah for her further elaboration.  I spent some time yesterday in my speech talking about the diverse needs of the patient and, therefore, the need for diversity.  From my point of view, that is a critical point.  You can have a very uniform system which was what I grew up with when I was a young officer starting my career in Singapore.  From the headquarters' point of view, it is the simplest - one circular and everybody follows, everybody wears the same uniform, etc.

 

     But I think that world is gone. And I gave some illustrations yesterday - different kinds of needs.  It is very hard for us to group them into simple boxes. For general policies, we have no choice but to simplify.  But reality requires us in each case, to try to be able to meet the unique needs.  That is why we restructured the hospitals and we have clusters, and we continue to evolve.  I do not see that the current structure will go on forever.  I am sure we will continue to evolve. Even during my term as Health Minister, I am quite sure that it will continue to evolve.

 

     And yes, what it means is that, once you allow that kind of diversity, we are paying a price for it. We are paying some price for diversity. So the challenge in management is to know what we should standardise and centralise, and what we should allow diversity. There are always trade-offs and we will continue to make that kind of trade-offs and judgement calls. Sometimes, we miss something and when a feedback is received, we will take a look at them.  That will be my general comments on this point about duplication and higher costs.  I think it is inevitable, provided the price, compared to the benefits that we get out of diversity, is worthwhile.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam): Sir, first, let me thank Dr Lily Neo and Dr Ong Seh Hong for their very useful comments.  I agree with the thrust of their remarks.

     My first response is focused on the broad question that they have asked  - how are we preparing our young for the future,

 

 

a globalised future or, as Dr Ong put it, a flat world, but also a future in which the greatest advantage for Singapore will come from our being a global city connected to the region and beyond?

 

     Some of the challenges we face are no different from those of any other developed society.  We know we have to work smarter, not work cheaper, in order to thrive, despite the competition from China and India, and before too long from new players like Vietnam.  What does working smart mean?  We ask employers regularly and we also keep our eyes out on what the other leading cities are doing to prepare for the future.  Working smart means that we have to prepare our young to think for themselves, so that they can kick start new ideas and solve problems as they come up, including problems they have not seen before.  Working smart also means working in smart teams, first-class teams - teams that use every talent and strength to come up with new solutions, and teams which stay resilient in the face of challenges, upright like bamboo.  And working smart means being able to communicate clearly and to be totally comfortable with IT skills. 

 

     These are the key skills for the future in any industry and at every level of the organisation.  It is what employers everywhere from the US to India to Europe are saying.  They need more people who can think for themselves, play in a team and communicate effectively with each other, real time.

 

     There is no single solution in education for developing these skills for the future.  As both Dr Lily Neo and Dr Ong have said, it is also not something that ends when students leave school.  We need more second chances and need the whole plethora of opportunities for lifelong learning.  But the foundations we set in school are critical.  It also does not mean doing many more new things in school, new subjects and new programmes.  A good part of what we want to do is already there in our schools and just needs to be done better or given sharper focus.  But it helps to have a more holistic and well-rounded education.  That is why we have been taking meaningful steps in that direction, towards a broader and more flexible approach in the way our students go about their academic learning and also a better balance between training the academic and non-academic skills.  MOS Lui Tuck Yew will say more on this later.

 

     We are also investing in ICT for learning - first, to make the whole learning experience more innovative and engaging, but also because essential ICT skills have to be second nature to our young and future Singaporeans.

 

     There is a further, critical dimension to educating our young for the future and which matters more to us than to other developed countries.  For Singapore to be a global city, we need to have a global outlook in our people.  The whole tenor of our society has to be about looking outward and welcoming new people into Singapore to live and work.  It will give us a big advantage in Asia if we do this well.  That is why we have to groom young Singaporeans who feel quite comfortable working and collaborating with people who come from all over the place, looking for opportunities and new markets outside Singapore, and working in places quite different from Singapore.  A good understanding of Asia, in particular, where opportunities are the largest, will also give them an advantage.  Developing a global outlook in our students is therefore an important strategy for MOE.  We want to nurture Singaporeans who are culturally versatile but confident of their own identity.

 

     The first way we are doing this is by providing more overseas opportunities for our students, so that from young, they get a sense of the complexities and opportunities in the region.  As Dr Ong has noted, these opportunities will also give them a better understanding of different cultures.  Last year, about 22,600 students and 4,000 teachers from our schools and junior colleges went overseas, either on school twinning programmes, overseas community involvement programmes or study trips of one form or another.  This year, we will see many more.  In fact, next week alone, the March school holidays, we have about 3,300 students from 60 schools going abroad, more than six times the number a year ago.  The March school holidays - amongst the four school holidays - the numbers are in fact the lowest.  This year, we have already seen a six-fold increase compared to a year ago.  So the schools are keen and the momentum is building up.

 

     We are also exploring opportunities for a few of our schools to establish satellite campuses in overseas cities so that our students can spend a longer time immersing themselves and interacting with their counterparts there while continuing to benefit from the Singapore curriculum.  Hwa Chong Institution already plans to establish a satellite campus in Beijing this year so that students in the Bi-cultural Studies Programme and other interested students can have more sustained exposure to contemporary China.  So not just a one or two-week study trip but you spend a few months there.

 

     Our tertiary institutions are also linking up with partners abroad through school-student exchanges and internships, and in the case of our universities also through collaborative research as well as joint degree programmes.  This is the way to go for our universities.  Overall, we aim to provide opportunities for up to 50% of our tertiary students to have an overseas stint during the course of their studies in a Singapore institution.

 

     We will continue to expand on these initiatives in the schools, JCs and in the tertiary institutions.  No other Asian city is making as determined a move to nurture in its citizens a sense of the world out there, a sense of the opportunities.  We have to do more of it than others because our future lies in being a global city.  Because we can only succeed by being a global city, and if we do it well, it will give us advantage over time.

 

     The second way we are preparing our young for the future as a global city is by training them in the languages.  I agree with both Dr Ong Seh Hong and Dr Lily Neo about the importance we have to place on this area.  Our bilingual language competency and our diverse range of languages are together a key strength for Singapore.  Competence in English and the mother tongue language, amongst the majority of young Singaporeans, will give us competitive edge over any other Asian city for years to come.  It also gives us our distinctive identity as a people, sharing a common cultural heritage with many other Asian cities but unique in the openness and vibrance of our multi-cultural society.

 

     MOE is taking steps to consolidate and add to Singapore's language advantage in three areas.  First, by improving the effectiveness of bilingual language learning including providing greater support for the small minority mother tongues as second language options.  Second, we will introduce more third language options like Bahasa Indonesia and Arabic, so that we can reach out to emerging areas outside Singapore.  As the Prime Minister mentioned at last year's National Day Rally, we have to do more to keep our immigrant cultures alive and also make it easy for Singaporeans to learn third languages, new foreign languages, that will help them to link up with opportunities outside.  Third, we will provide opportunities for more students to learn languages other than their own mother tongue at a conversational level so as to enhance interaction among Singaporeans of different races and strengthen our social cohesion even as we embrace the world.

 

     Over the past three years, as Members know, MOE has conducted comprehensive reviews of each of the four official languages - English and the three main mother tongue languages (Chinese, Malay, Tamil).  The implementation of the changes arising from these reviews will be a key focus for MOE and our schools over the next few years.  We have already seen some results in the mother tongue languages, with language learning coming alive through a more flexible curriculum, creative teaching methods and an increased emphasis on oral skills so that students keep using their mother tongues after they leave school.  More of our students are pursuing a high level of excellence in their mother tongues.  We have seen from this year, the full effects of the progressive relaxation in the eligibility criteria for students wishing to offer Higher Mother Tongue Languages which we started a few years ago.  Today, 34% of Secondary One students are taking Higher Chinese compared to 21% in 2003.  For Higher Malay, the proportion has risen from 11% to 19%, and for Higher Tamil, it is an increase from 17% to 36%, or more than double.

To broaden access to Tamil instruction,eight more secondary schools will offer Tamil Language within curriculum time from next year.      MOE will also work with our primary schools to provide pro-active advice to parents of their graduating classes, the P6 classes, to send their children to secondary schools which offer Tamil Language during curriculum time, so that they do not need to travel in the afternoon to classes elsewhere.  With more students enrolled in these schools which offer Tamil Language during regular curriculum time, they can practise the language with their peers, and benefit from a richer learning environment for the language.

 

     I will now touch on the non-Tamil Indian languages, which are the mother tongues for the smaller Indian minority groups.  These languages are not new to Singapore.  In fact, they go as far back as Stamford Raffles and in some cases, much earlier, to the old trading routes for which Singapore was a port of call.  We must keep them alive so that they remain a vibrant part of Singapore’s cultural landscape.  Like Tamil, they allow our communities to link up to different parts of South Asia. The number of students learning Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Punjabi and Urdu as their second language has grown by about 20% over the past five years, to about 4,800 students today.    The communities have done a commendable job in organising instruction for their children.  The Board for Teaching and Testing of South Asian Languages currently oversees the delivery of non-Tamil Indian language instruction by the different community bodies, as well as overseeing the standardisation of the examinations they conduct.

 

     MOE has provided for the five non-Tamil Indian languages to be part of our national examinations at the PSLE, "N" and "O" levels, and at the "AO" levels as well.  We have provided for this since the first half of 1990s.  To help the communities keep their mother tongues alive, we have decided to provide funding support for the non-Tamil Indian languages.  MOE will now provide a grant of about $1.5 million each year to enable the Board for Teaching and Testing of South Asian Languages and the community groups to provide subsidies for students taking these classes.  In addition, MOE will work with the Board to effect the necessary processes to facilitate the recognition of grades in these languages for students' level-to-level progression within their schools before they get to the milestone years where they take the national examinations which MOE conducts.  We will also allow them to use their language grades to count towards their eligibility for Edusave awards such as the Good Progress Award and Edusave scholarships.  I hope this encourages them to excel in their mother tongues.

     It is examples like these that bring home the point that our programmes are working; they are reaching down to groups that need help.  So we will step up our efforts to establish a national qualification system based on the WSQ framework and employability skills system (ESS).  We will  build more quality institutions to deliver high-quality training.  Because it is only through high-quality institutions that will allow Singaporeans to have portable qualifications, which take into account their previous work experience.  And when they pursue further training, they have the assurance that their skills obtained will be recognised by their next employer.  We cannot guarantee that retrenchments would not occur - a point raised by Dr Lim Wee Kiak.  Even as the economy grows, there were about 10,000 retrenchments.  That is the nature of this globalised world.  Product cycles are short.  There is a quick turnaround.  Obsolescence is quick.  Workers need to be retrenched but you have to get them new jobs and train them.

 

     We will progressively cover more sectors through our WSQ framework.  Last year, 32,000 received WSQ and ESS Statements of Attainment.  While the numbers are encouraging, we will do more.

 

     Let me now touch on specific initiatives for groups of workers who face specific challenges, which Members have mentioned.  Mr Low mentioned older workers.  Mr Yeo Guat Kwang and Mrs Josephine Teo also talked about the structurally unemployed, including those whom we call contract workers.

 

     Let me first say that the situation has improved.  One of the lessons learnt is that a rising tide does indeed lift all boats, including the ones who are structurally unemployed, or at risk or vulnerable workers.  In other words, somehow, the labour market absorbs these people who were deemed less employable.  The long-term unemployed - which is a proxy, if you are unemployed for more than 25 weeks - is now 0.8% of the resident labour force, which is about 15,000 residents.  From 2001 to 2004,

 

 

it rose to as high as 1.5%, so almost double that.  I need to put that 0.8% into context.  All societies, as the economy is developed and becomes higher value add, will have a layer which they find it hard to keep up.  Our structural unemployment rate or long-term unemployment rate is actually substantially better compared to many developed countries.  For example, in the US, it is 1%; in Germany, it is 6.7%; in France, it is 5.8%.  So much of Europe has got much higher rates of about five to ten times what we have.  That is no excuse for us to let up our efforts but I want to give Members a sense of the perspective that as we move up, there will be a group that will find it hard to catch up and we must spend more efforts.  But let us not be discouraged by that number.

 

     WDA and the self-help groups developed a new CareerLink Plus Programme in August last year - self-help groups like Mendaki, CDAC, SINDA and other groups - specifically for the long-term unemployed.  I think that is the right way to do this - through community help groups which have a better reach to this group, and the programme offers counselling services to better prepare this group for the changing demands of the job market.  Together, they helped about 540 cases and placed more than 200 individuals.  Not a large number to crow about but it is a start, and I want them to ramp up this programme.

 

     Another way we can help this group is through the Job Re-Creation Programme (JRP), a point raised by Mr Low Thia Khiang and Ms Cham Hui Fong.  The JRP identifies jobs, upscales them, re-creates them to increase the pay and productivity.  Members have asked for some numbers.  Last year, it re-created about 12,000 jobs and placed over 7,000 workers.  Of this, more importantly, 50% were mature workers and 54% were lower skilled.  To tap on the good opportunities in the labour market for Singaporeans, we will expand the JRP.  This is the right time to do it.  It is going to increase from 23 to 27 sectors to include banking and finance, call centre, manufacturing as well as the electronics and spa industry, on top of the existing ones such as retail, tourism and F&B. 

 

     Members have touched on PMETs (Professionals, Managers, Executives and Technicians) in this Budget Debate - Dr Lim Wee Kiak, Ms Denise Phua, Ms Jessica Tan, Mr Zaqy Mohamad and Mrs Josephine Teo.  Sir, let me turn my attention to this. They are quite right.  We do need coordinated support.  We need to make sure that our programmes are coherent, and they know where to go.  But I want to sound a word of caution.  It does get more difficult. I want to be realistic. 

 

     For the low-wage workers, we have instituted Workfare systemic measures.  As we move up the spectrum, it becomes a bit more difficult because the PMET is his best value.  He finally is the one that needs to be convinced because he is a professional, well-educated and well-qualified.  Some of them, as Members have rightly pointed out, are over-qualified.  As our economy restructures, the first thing that I would tell Members is that more, rather than fewer, PMET openings will be in the job market.  I think that is a source of comfort, but let me give Members some numbers.

 

     Last year, the PMET-type of jobs made up 37% of job openings and, indeed, we expect this trend to increase because we are moving up the value chain.  Out of the 450,000 jobs which I have mentioned will come onstream, and we project in the next five years, over half, 50% to 60%, will be PMET job openings.  Consistent with these statistics, many industry sectors have indicated that they will indeed need more PMETs in jobs such as software engineers, electronic engineers, budgeting and financial accounting managers as well as nurses, to name a few.  Many of these jobs will need to be filled by people who transit from one sector to another because you cannot stop sectors from downsizing or upsizing.  We do not have the ability.  No government has the ability to try to control it in such a way that you really know what to do because you cannot be ahead of the curve, and you can only respond sometimes.  WDA indeed does help them and we placed about 3,800 PMETs to available jobs, but I think we need to think of better strategies.

 

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked: what will the IRs do for PMETs?  Indeed, each IR is expected to hire over 1,000 PMETs in jobs such as customer service executives, management executives, retail and sales managers and restaurant services managers.  While the job openings may be there, it may be in sectors different from what the people were used to.  Recruitment for the IRs will be in phases and the bulk of the jobs are expected to be filled in 2009.  WDA is already working with the two IRs to identify the skills and training programmes needed, in order to upskill locals, as well as for opportunities in the larger tourism sector.  But I am also happy to tell Members that other institutions are involved. 

 

     WDA is tying up with At-sunrice and SHATEC and the University of Nevada, Las Vegas to train MICE executives.  These are not "mice"; these are, as you know, meetings, incentive, conventions and exhibitions.  But we have also local institutions that are coming onstream.  Temasek Polytechnic is offering new diplomas in culinary and catering management, and leisure and resort management.  Singapore Polytechnic has a new tourism and resort management diploma.  The University of Nevada, Las Vegas has set up an overseas campus here, offering a Bachelor of Science degree in Hotel Administration as well as the Executive Masters' in Hospitality Administration.

 

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked if many of the retrenched PMETs who found a job ended up with lower-paying jobs.  In our system, the market determines the value of the job.  It is difficult for Government or, indeed, any agency to say, well, since your previous job was this, you should be paid this in the next job.  All of us know that it is unrealistic, nobody will quite listen to us and, if we try to do it, we would fail.  Individuals, especially the PMETs themselves, will have to prove their own worth and increase their value.  What is more critical is to help displaced PMETs upgrade, refresh their skills and find new sectors that they can expand their choices and make full use of the opportunities and, over time, as their value increases, they can look forward to higher salaries. 

 

     To help PMETs, Members have asked that we be proactive, and I am happy to announce that WDA will launch a new programme.  It is called the Professionals Conversion Programme (PCP).  PCP will cost the Government $20 million over the next two years and it will enable 1,000 PMETs to start new careers in growth sectors.  It is modelled very much after our previous programmes where we will help convert  professionals to nurses.  This PCP will cover new and growing sectors such as finance, marine, aerospace and tourism, including F&B, infocomm technology and creative industries, because these are the expanding sectors.  So we will help PMETs transit to these new sectors.

 

     I mentioned earlier that the projected manpower demand over the next five years is over 450,000 jobs.  The already tight labour market will get even tighter.  Up to a point, as Mrs Josephine Teo mentioned, this is good because wages will rise.  But if costs go up too fast, as she rightly pointed out, ahead of productivity or if businesses cannot meet their manpower needs, then we become less competitive and could lose opportunities for future growth.

 

     Mrs Teo also rightly pointed out that every year, we only have about 33,000 locals.  That is the size of our supply.  And because of our ageing population and falling birth rates, it will actually decline.  Post-2010, the growth rate will actually drop.  I have circulated the charts to show that the employment rates of working age males are already as high as that in other developed countries.  We are among the highest in the world for those number of working.  Now, I need to explain "employment rate".  This is a figure which is the ultimate in employment statistics.  It just measures the number of physical bodies you have and how many in that pool is working.  This is not like unemployment rate.  Because to be unemployed, you must be looking for work, and if you are not looking for work, then you cannot be unemployed.  But the employment rate does not care whether you are looking for work or not.  It just asks a question: do you exist, first; and if you exist, how many of those who are existing are working?  So it is the absolute measurement, if you like.  It is nearly 90%.  We are among the highest in the world, on par with Japan but ahead of many OECD countries.  I have also circulated a chart on employment rates for women, just to complete the picture.  It is much better for cohorts of younger women, but it could be improved for cohorts of older women.

 

     We are literally running out of physical bodies to fill up new jobs that are coming onstream.  450,000 divided by five is about 90,000 new jobs, but we have only a supply of 33,000 and we have reached maximum.  We will have to persuade existing workers to work longer.  Fewer older women are working, so we may have to expand efforts and encourage them to come back to the workforce.  But these efforts, as Members recognise, will take time.  Depending on our local workforce alone will constrain our growth potential.  Therefore, we will have to judiciously use foreign manpower to supplement our local workforce to meet demand.  "We do not intend to shoot ourselves in the foot", a quote that Mrs Teo used.  So to maintain our economic momentum, MOM will be making certain adjustments to help businesses meet their increasing needs for manpower.

 

     In doing so, I also want to address concerns of Members of this House and the public that there must be a balance in allowing foreign workers here, so that Singaporeans will ultimately benefit as the economic pie grows.  I will, therefore, not increase foreign worker quotas.  The quotas will stay.  The only exceptions to this are for the construction and process sectors which have a large demand for manpower.  Mrs Teo asked us to be selective.  This is one selective way.  Except for the construction and process sectors, the quotas for all other industries will stay the same but within the existing cap, certain rules will be relaxed to help businesses source for and retain experienced foreign workers.

 

     First, I will raise the 'S' Pass quota.  To help meet the industry demand for skilled foreign workers, we will allow companies greater access to 'S' Pass holders.  The 'S' Pass holders will be increased to 15% from the present 10%.  But the additional 5% will come from the companies' existing work permit quota.  So, the quota is not raised, and if you want more 'S' Passes, you take it from your work permit quota and you can bring more 'S' Passes in.  In other words, they can recruit more 'S' Passes, but the total proportion of work permit and 'S' Pass holders remains the same.  This will take effect from 1st June 2007.

 

     Second, I will extend the maximum employment period for work permit holders.  Currently, skilled and unskilled work permit holders can be employed for a maximum of 15 years and four years respectively.   To help employers retain their work permit holders longer in a tight labour market, MOM will extend the maximum employment period for skilled and unskilled work permit holders to 18 and six years respectively, ie, a three and two years' extension basically.  This will take effect from 1st April 2007.

 

     Third, certain aspects relating to the construction sector.  Dr Lim Wee Kiak's example, notwithstanding, this is the sector that is really under pressure to build.  I think we need to be easier on them.  They have problems with sand and granite and I do not want workers to be another thing to be on their mind.  The Building and Construction Authority has projected that this sector's annual output will rise to between $14 billion to $17 billion for the next few years, up from the average of about $12 billion in the past three years, so almost a 14% rise.  Naturally, this will increase the demand for construction manpower and BCA estimates that we will need another 40,000 to 50,000 foreign workers over the next two to three years.  So to ease the manpower pressure, we will adopt the following measures from 1st April 2007:

 

     (i) The sectoral dependency ratio will be increased from 1:4 to 1:5;

 

     (ii) We have intended to increase their productivity by cutting their Man Year Entitlement (MYE) for each project by 5%.  We have decided to hold back this reduction and just allow them to use the existing Man Year Entitlement formula.  We do want our projects to be finished on time; and

 

     (iii) Currently, the MYE is also waived for construction workers who have worked for any employer for at least six years.  I will shorten this to four years.  This will increase the pool to about 73,000 workers who will not require a Man Year Entitlement.

 

     Next, on the process industry.  This is a sector that deals with petrochemicals related to building the plants and other aspects.  The process industry is poised for a major boom up to 2010 due to the robust growth in Asia's energy markets and China's increasing demand for petrochemicals.  To harness this growth, from 1st April 2007, we will increase the dependency ratio to 1:5 from the current 1:4, and we will also allow contractors to cross-deploy their workers.

 

     We will monitor the effectiveness of these changes and make further adjustments, if necessary, as warranted by the employment conditions.

 

     While changing or relaxing some of these measures, I want to reassure Members that we have taken their potential concerns into account.

 

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked how we can increase the productivity of construction workers.  I, too, want it to increase and BCA, I understand, is working together with MND to build a core of localised skilled workers in key construction trades.  BCA is also working with industry to enhance their construction productivity to adopt more buildable designs and innovative construction methods.  We will try to reduce our reliance on foreign workers but, in the meantime, let us relax the rules a bit and let them build what we need to build and then, in tandem, try to increase their productivity.

       Indeed, we have to calibrate the foreign manpower controls.  But we need to be mindful that globalisation is a two-way street.  Just as we have taken, in Singapore, business opportunities away from others because we are more competitive and responsive, we should remind ourselves that others can steal the march from us too. From 2001 to 2006, about 240,000 jobs created were taken up by locals, and about 85,000 jobs went to foreigners. Put it in another way, for every one foreign worker we judiciously allowed in, nearly three jobs were created for locals.  If we choked off growth and employment creation, if we controlled it too tightly, we would drive investments to competing locations.  Because, ultimately, Singapore companies must compete globally.  So ensuring that companies have met their manpower needs, both foreigner and local, will translate into greater opportunities and benefits for Singapore and Singaporeans.

 

     Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked how MOM, even as we liberalise, can strengthen the framework to protect the well-being of foreign workers and to guard against potential abuse by arrogant employers.  In tandem with these measures, we will tighten up.  The Employment of Foreign Workers Act will be amended to stiffen penalties for selected offences and introduce new offences.  The powers of MOM's Employment Inspectors will also be strengthened so that they can effectively enforce the laws.  In other words, we are changing some aspects of the Employment of Foreign Workers Act. We will also link work permit approvals to foreign worker housing.  Moving forward, MOM will require employers, at the point of application of work permits, to provide information to where they intend to house their foreign workers.  It is a reasonable request.  You want to bring them in, where do you intend to house them?  MOM will not approve the applications if the accommodations do not meet specified conditions.  We will announce the implementation details at a later day.

 

     Mr Yeo Guat Kwang asked for an update on the medical insurance.  We are tying up with insurers to see for those who need to, how they can buy into this insurance.  Many employers already have medical insurance for their foreign workers.  But those who need it will have a plan which they can buy into.

 

     We will also review the Workmen's Compensation Act to ensure that it continues to safeguard the interests of injured workers, both local and foreign, while at the same time deter and hold accountable irresponsible and errant employers or workers.  MOM will examine the Act's coverage, compensation formula and the compensation levels.  We also plan to enhance MOM's enforcement powers to ensure that workers receive their due compensation promptly while at the same time protect the interests of workers or employers for fraudulent claims. 

 

     Mr Yeo has asked for an update on the portable medical benefits scheme. My Minister of State will elaborate on this.

 

     The various policies and initiatives that I have covered will support growth and enhance opportunities for all.  A strong and dynamic economy requires an equally resilient and dynamic workforce - one that embraces opportunities, adapts quickly to changing realities; one that is open and welcoming to talent from abroad, drawing strengths from within and outside Singapore.  If we close ourselves to chance, if we close ourselves to opportunities, then we shrink.  We are poised to move up the ranks of developed nations if we hold steadfast together with these policies that have gotten us here and allow us to sail ahead on the crest of globalisation.  I say to Singaporeans that we can face the future with confidence and optimism, with an abundance of job opportunities ahead.  But they must scale up to make the most of these opportunities because new jobs that are coming will be of higher value-add in the new sectors.
